page.title: 08HISTORY OF THE SCHOOL
page.content: The school was founded in 1645, when Sir John Offley left provision for two stone school houses. One was for boys, for the learning of Latin, English and Accounting; the other for girls, for the learning of English and Needlework. The building cost was 100 pounds.Annual salaries were paid of 30, 20, and 10 pounds respectively to a schoolmaster, an usher, and a schoolmistress. Little is known of the development of the school in the 18th Century, as no records were kept, but in 1804 Samuel Stretch left money in his will for "A Pretty Scholar Bell." The school was rebuilt in 1876, shortly after the 1870 Act made educ- ation compulsory. A series of alterat- ions and additions have been made since that time, and although a state school, the school has retained its individual- ity and its links with the Church.
